should i use powershell or the x86 version of it? what difference?

The choice between using PowerShell and the x86 version of PowerShell depends on your specific needs and situation.

PowerShell is a powerful command-line interface and scripting language that can be used for various tasks such as system administration, automation, and data analysis. The x86 version of PowerShell is designed to run on 32-bit systems or to interact with 32-bit applications on 64-bit systems.

If you are working with a 32-bit system, you may need to use the x86 version of PowerShell. On the other hand, if you are working on a 64-bit system and are interacting with 64-bit applications or system components, it is recommended to use the standard version of PowerShell.

In general, the standard version of PowerShell should be your default choice, but if you have specific needs related to 32-bit systems or applications, you may need to use the x86 version. It’s important to consider your specific requirements and the compatibility of the applications you are working with when deciding which version of PowerShell to use.
can i run commands in powershell like regular cmd prompt?

Yes, you can run commands in PowerShell just like you would in a regular CMD prompt. In fact, PowerShell supports most of the same commands and syntax as CMD prompt, so many of the commands you are familiar with should work in PowerShell.

However, PowerShell also has its own set of commands and features that are not available in CMD prompt. PowerShell allows you to work with objects and their properties, making it easier to automate and manage complex tasks. It also includes a powerful scripting language that allows you to write and execute custom scripts to automate repetitive tasks.

To launch PowerShell, you can simply type "powershell" into the Start menu or Run dialog box on a Windows system. Once you have launched PowerShell, you can start running commands just like you would in a regular CMD prompt.
is "when you don't have a hammer, nails are invisible" the corollary to "when all you have is a hammer every problem looks like a nail"?

Yes, "when you don't have a hammer, nails are invisible" is often considered the corollary to "when all you have is a hammer every problem looks like a nail". 

The phrase "when all you have is a hammer" implies that when you are only familiar with or have access to a limited set of tools, you are more likely to approach every problem with the same solution or perspective. This can lead to a lack of creativity and problems being solved in a suboptimal way.

On the other hand, "when you don't have a hammer, nails are invisible" suggests that when you lack the right tool for a particular task, you may not even recognize that the problem exists, or that there is a solution available. This can be especially true when dealing with complex problems or tasks that require specialized knowledge or tools.

Taken together, these phrases emphasize the importance of having the right tools and skills for a given task, and being able to approach problems from a variety of perspectives in order to find the best solution.
